instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1370: What is A1370? A1370 is a model number for a 11 inch size MacBook Air from years Late 2010, Mid 2011 with EMC 2393, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-2796, 820-3024..
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.820-3024: What is 820-3024? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.PP5V_S3: What is PP5V_S3? PP5V_S3 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S3 suspend to RAM state..
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H: What is PPDCIN_G3H? PPDCIN_G3H Is a power rail that comes directly from the laptop charger..
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.5V_S3: What is 5V_S3? 5V_S3 is an abbreviation of “PP5V_S3” which is a 5 volt power rail present in an S3 state. S3 (Suspend to RAM) is a state where the system saves its context to RAM, a faster but more power-consuming method than S4. The system shuts down most components except for RAM, which remains powered to retain the system state. PM_SLP_S4_L is required for this rail to be present. .
definitions.U7201: What is U7201? U7201 is responsible for the 3.3v and 5v power rails on many devices..

threads.title: [SOLVED] MacAir wont start; blinking green/orange light {short to ground on 5v bus}
threads.message:
Hello, I have a MacAir 2011 <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1370</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>  BRD: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3024</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B that doesn't turn on. It doesn't have any history of water damage. Every time I connect the magsafe (60W) to the computer it flashes green and orange very rapidly. I have taken some measurements and from what I can see the computer fails to switch to the S0 state due to a short on <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL>. Please correct me if I'm wrong. I have tried to inject some voltage into this line to find the short but nothing is getting hot. I have checked the charging circuitry (<CHIP>U7000</CHIP>) and it looks ok. I don't have a good board to compare. Any ideas? Thanks!

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>   8.35v   (12.8v)
<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> 17.06v (12.8v)
<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>  3.40v   (3.42v)

<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> 4.80v  
*<SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> 0v  
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> 0.17 

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> 3.32v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S3</SIGNAL> 0.24v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL>

threads.title: [SOLVED] MacAir wont start; blinking green/orange light {short to ground on 5v bus}
threads.message: What is the resistance to GND on <SIGNAL>5V_S3</SIGNAL> then?

threads.title: [SOLVED] MacAir wont start; blinking green/orange light {short to ground on 5v bus}
threads.message:
No Title

If I switch my meter to beep test and put my red probe on <SIGNAL>5V_S3</SIGNAL> and my black probe on a screw hole it gives me 2.2ohms. It also beeps. Is this what you mean? From what I can see, <SIGNAL>5V_S3</SIGNAL> gets initiated from <CHIP>U7201</CHIP>. I have taken some measurements on this chip and it looks like it's missing en1. Should I try to inject some voltage on en1 to see if the machine turns on?

threads.title: [SOLVED] MacAir wont start; blinking green/orange light {short to ground on 5v bus}
threads.message:
[QUOTE="dukefawks, post: 2089"]What is the resistance to GND on <SIGNAL>5V_S3</SIGNAL> then?[/QUOTE]

If I switch my meter to beep test and put my red probe on <SIGNAL>5V_S3</SIGNAL> and my black probe on a screw hole it gives me 2.2ohms. It also beeps. Is this what you mean? From what I can see, <SIGNAL>5V_S3</SIGNAL> gets initiated from <CHIP>U7201</CHIP>. I have taken some measurements on this chip and it looks like it's missing en1. Should I try to inject some voltage on en1 to see if the machine turns on?

threads.title: [SOLVED] MacAir wont start; blinking green/orange light {short to ground on 5v bus}
threads.message: You need to find the short on the <SIGNAL>5V_S3</SIGNAL> bus first. There are MANY things connected to this bus so it is best to inject a voltage to the shorted bus and see what component is heating up. Start with 1V and slowly go up if nothing seems to heat. Do not go over 3V of course.

threads.title: [SOLVED] MacAir wont start; blinking green/orange light {short to ground on 5v bus}
threads.message:
[QUOTE="dukefawks, post: 2127"]You need to find the short on the <SIGNAL>5V_S3</SIGNAL> bus first. There are MANY things connected to this bus so it is best to inject a voltage to the shorted bus and see what component is heating up. Start with 1V and slowly go up if nothing seems to heat. Do not go over 3V of course.[/QUOTE]


Did I measure the resistance to ground correctly?

threads.title: [SOLVED] MacAir wont start; blinking green/orange light {short to ground on 5v bus}
threads.message:
No Title

Problem fixed!! I found the short on <SIGNAL>5V_S3</SIGNAL>

threads.title: [SOLVED] MacAir wont start; blinking green/orange light {short to ground on 5v bus}
